results.title: Visual instincts : Australian contemporary photographers
results.brief_description: A series which looks at the state of photography in Australia today, by either focusing on the work of individuals or on exhibitions and collections.

results.title: Grant Mudford. Max Pam
results.creator_credit: Jeff Atkinson, Roger Young, Brian Beaton, Kevin Ballantine and Izon Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Visual instincts : Australian contemporary photographers”.
Two thirty minute programs: 1. “Grant Mudford” Born in Australia in 1944, photographer, Grant Mudford, now lives and works in California. He prefers anonymous architectural subject matter photographed in a manner that transforms it. 2. “Max Pam” Born in Melbourne, Max Pam left at age 19 for Katmandu. He returned to Australia in 1984 having established an international reputation as a photographer of Asia. Photography, for Pam, has the capacity to capture certain moments which elude the writer, the filmmaker or the painter.

results.title: Seventeen
results.creator_credit: Jeff Kreines, Joel DeMott, DeMott and Kreines Films
results.brief_description: A group of American working-class teenagers were filmed during their last year at high school. DeMott and Kreines filmed for more than a year and by living where they filmed, they covered a wide range of adolescent experiences. No cuts were made and the film reflects exactly what they saw.

results.title: Visually speaking. Parts 1-6
results.creator_credit: Don White, Yaletown Productions Inc. and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: 1. “Body talking”. Begins the sequence by exploring the power of visual images as a source of information and means of communication. 2.”A sense of touch” 3. “A sense of sound”. These two segments extend the power of visual imagery by showing how it connects with information from other senses to enrich the meaning we gain from our experiences. 4. “Speaking object-ly”. Provides a transition from the literal interpretation of visual imagery to the more abstract concept that what we see carries implicit subjective messages. 5. “Sequence and story”. Shows how visual images are connected to one another and how our interpretations can be changed as we explore how our images of them are related to one another. 6. “Movie movie”. Deals directly with ways in which visual images can be manipulated to influence our thoughts and emotions.

results.title: Emmanuel Angelicas & Jon Lewis
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ballantine, Brian Beaton and Izon Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Visual instincts : Australian contemporary photographers”.
Two half hour episodes: 1. Marrickville photographer, Emmanuel Angelicas, talks on the sources and themes of his photography - sex, violence, television and religion. He enforces his style through his sense of composition, Greek tradition and a particular detachment from his surroundings. 2. Jon Lewis, Sydney photographer, is a paparazzi with a human face. It is his scrutiny of the bright lights and big city of Sydney that singles him out as an outstanding chronicler of public Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kevin Ballantine, Brian Beaton and Izon Productions

results.title: Seven shades of pale
results.creator_credit: Les Rose, William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From a quiet, neglected corner of Nova Scotia, a meeting with the Black community that shows both the traditional attitudes of the older generation and the more alert, resolved stance of the young. The old still pin their hopes on the church and the preacher, while the young look more towards the Black United Front and its roving director. For both generations change is a challenge. The common hope is for a fuller life.

results.title: Wm Bligh
results.creator_credit: John Croyston, Alan Burke, ABC and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Behind the Legend”.
Presents a dramatized re-enactment of the events surrounding the arrest of Governor William Bligh by the New South Wales Corps in 1808. Various witnesses present their accounts of cowardice and misappropriation by Bligh. Introduced by Manning Clark and written by Thomas Keneally. Cast includes Brian James as Bligh, Peter Gwynne, Richard Meikle, Kevin Leslie, John Trenaman, Robyn Nevin.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Croyston, Alan Burke, ABC and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Seven little Australians: Eps. 4-6
results.creator_credit: Ron Way, Charles Russell, ABC and Ethel Turner Productions
results.brief_description: The story of the Woolcot family, living in Sydney in the 1890’s. An Englishman in the New South Wales Regiment, Captain Woolcot is constantly harassed and embarrassed by the antics of his seven mischievous children: Meg, Pip, Judy, Nell, Bunty, Baby and ‘The General’. Episode 4: All for the worst: Bunty is plagued by the lies he tells, Meg makes efforts to be ‘grown up’ and Judy makes a tortuous trip home. Episode 5: Secrets: Judy arrives home worn out and ill, but makes the other children promise not to let Esther or the Captain know for fear of being sent back to school. Episode 6: Tomorrow do thy worst: Judy is still ill and the children try to take care of her. However, the Captain’s suspicions are aroused and he discovers Judy’s hiding place.
